results.title: Running
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “1976 Olympic Films”.
Compiled as a visual aid to coaching and physical education, this film collects silent, slow-motion footage of the men’s track events at the 1976 Montreal Olympics.

results.title: [Various women's athletic events from the 1976 Olympic Games]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “1976 Olympic Films”
Shows various women’s events from the 1976 Olympic Games. Includes jumping events - pole vaulting, high jump, long jump and throwing events - shot put, javelin. Also shown are baton relay, running hurdles, endurance events. Silent film.

results.title: Eden et Apres = Eden and After
results.brief_description:
A group of students hang out at the Eden cafe, swapping tale of adventures and fantasies. The sudden arrival of a mysterious stranger upsets their collective daydreaming and starts a cycle of ‘surreal’ events.

Credits: Producer, Maurice Urbain ; director, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Igor Luther ; music, Michel Fano.
Cast: Catherine Jourdan, Pierre Zimmer, Lorraine Rainer, Sylvain Corthay, Richard Leduc.

results.title: Eden's Lost
results.creator_credit: Neil Armfield, Margaret Fink, ABC-TV (Australia) and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description: Based on a novel by Sumner Locke Elliott, this is the story of Angus Weekes and the unusual family of Eve St. James. Taken in by Eve after the death of his guardian, Angus cannot resist becoming involved in the ultimately tragic patterns of their lives. This is ‘art-television’ in the BBC tradition of literary adaptation. Like the novel it is structured in three parts. ‘Angus’ (episode I) is the most Gothic and melodramatic in structure and tone; ‘Bea’ (episode II) is the most naturalistic and ‘Eve’ (episode III) is the most concentrated and formally rigorous. Cast includes Julia Blake, Arthur Dignam, Linda Cropper, Victoria Longley and Bruce Hughes.

results.title: Ecstasy = Ekstase
results.brief_description: This controversial Czech film, featuring a very young Hedy Lamarr, gained international notoriety for its loose morals and a lengthy nude sequence. It was banned in America, Britain and Germany.

constellations_other.name: Weaponising glamour
constellations_other.description: Josephine Baker wasn't just a star, she was a spy with the French Resistance during the German occupation of France during WWII. She wasn't the only celebrity to weaponise her glamour.

results.description: This controversial Czech film, featuring a very young Hedy Lamarr, gained international notoriety for its loose morals and a lengthy nude sequence. It was banned in America, Britain and Germany. The story follows a young woman’s search for love and fulfillment after she marries an unloving and much older man. Eventually she leaves him to return to the family home where she falls in love with a handsome young surveyor, but her husband discovers the affair and takes drastic action. The story is straightforward melodrama but an effortless sensuality and remarkable cinematography give the film a freshness and eloquence that is quite special.
description_for_label: This controversial Czech film, featuring a very young Hedy Lamarr, gained international notoriety for its loose morals and a lengthy nude sequence. It was banned in America, Britain and Germany. The story follows a young woman’s search for love and fulfillment after she marries an unloving and much older man. Eventually she leaves him to return to the family home where she falls in love with a handsome young surveyor, but her husband discovers the affair and takes drastic action. The story is straightforward melodrama but an effortless sensuality and remarkable cinematography give the film a freshness and eloquence that is quite special.

results.title: Ecotoons
results.creator_credit: Claire Breese, Sally Richardson and WWF UK
results.brief_description: Presented by Tony Robinson (Blackadder’s Baldrick), this World Wildlife Fund compilation of 30 international animated shorts is aimed at increasing awareness of environmental issues. Using claymation, stop start animation and computer animation, the tales cover a variety of issues such as pollution, overdevelopment, water and energy conservation, the dumping of toxic waste, recycling, logging, extinction and the depletion of the ozone layer. Also includes footage from the BBC series “Going live” in which a 12 year old viewer won a competition to have her storyboard for a “Morph” episode with a “green” theme brought to animated life by the Aardman studios. She visits Peter Lord at the studios who explains the animation process.
